question: Question_01_(b)
sols:
If we simply try to plug in the value \emph{x} = 0, we obtain infinity
minus infinity, which is undefined (you can't say it is zero, it really
depends on the ``size'' of each infinity in some sense). So we first do
a little algebra to rewrite the two fractions as one, using a common
denominator:

\begin{align*}\frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1-2x}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{1-(1-2x)}{x(1-2x)} = \frac{2x}{x(1-2x)}\end{align*}
After canceling the \emph{x} we obtain something we can compute:

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 0} \left( \frac{1}{x(1-2x)} - \frac{1}{x} \right) = \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2}{1-2x} = 2\end{align*}
hints: A little algebra can get you a long way. Try simplifying the expression.
